questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle, formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Causes for pain/tenderness at the costovertebral angle include:

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) - caused by Hantavirus.

 

The boundaries of renal angle are formed by the lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of the erector spinae muscle.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? Note : The solid line is the original fluid compartment and the colour shaded compartment within the dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition.
questions.solution:
In adrenal insufficiency there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Aldosterone deficiency leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid).

  • The osmolarity of ECF decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into ICF; as a result of the shift, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction. 

Please note that in the diagram, the horizontal axis represents volume and vertical axis represents osmolarity. 

The Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions are shown above.

questions.text: A 1-year old boy presented with loss of motor skills increased startle response to noise and seizures. On fundoscopy, the following image was seen. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
An infant with neurological involvement and a cherry-red spot in the macula suggests the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay-Sachs disease is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides.

Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease are :

  • Loss of motor skills
  • Seizures
  • Hyperacusis
  • Macrocephaly
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Neurodegeneration
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness

Note: Clinical features of Sandhoff's disease is similar to Tay-Sachs but additionally have hepatosplenomegaly and cardiac involvement. It is due to defective Hexosaminidase A and B.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

questions.text: An 18-month-child with gonadal dysgenesis presents with a large abdominal mass. On resection, the gross appearance of the mass is as seen below. Which of the following tumors does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor).

The history of a large abdominal mass in a young child and the resected gross specimen, which shows well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes seen in the upper pole of the kidney, is strongly suggestive of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma). The history of gonadal dysgenesis aids the diagnosis of Wilms tumor, which is associated with Denys–Drash syndrome.

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma): It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (peaks 2-5 years of age).

Other options

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of adults.
  • Angiomyolipoma may rarely be seen in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla; however, it is not associated with gonadal dysgenesis. 

Image: The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components:

  1. Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).
  2. Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).
  3. Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady with recent onset, progressive dementia comes with myoclonus. The brain imaging is shown below. What biochemical component is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease(CJD), caused by prions. Prions are composed of protein.

These are infectious protein particles that lack any nucleic acid. They are filterable like viruses but are resistant to agents of sterilization. 

Prion proteins have two isoforms:

  • PrPSc is the prion protein that causes disease.
  • PrPc is the normal prion protein, found in human cells.

Prions cause diseases such as CJD, Kuru, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's.

Laboratory diagnosis of prion diseases:

  • Measurement of PrPSc by immunoassay
  • Brain MRI
  • Brain biopsy
  • Stress protein 14-3-3
  • Sequencing PRNP gene
  • Abnormal EEG

questions.text: Which of the following anti-rheumatoid drugs can cause this?
questions.solution:
The image shows bull’s eye maculopathy.

Hydroxychloroquine use is associated with this side effect.

questions.text:
Identify the following poisonous snakes.
  1. Common krait
  2. Russell viper
  3. Saw scaled viper
  4. King cobra
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Related Pearl: Identification of Poisonous Snakes

Snake Identification
 Common Cobra  Hooded with spectacle mark
King cobra Hooded without spectacle mark
Common krait Single/double white bands on body
Russell viper
Three rows of diamond shape black/brown spots.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the finding as shown below. She is diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage.
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of a Morgagnian hyper-mature cataract.

Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile cataract:

  • Cortical (soft cataract)- 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract)- 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments.

  • Cataracta brunescens (brown)
  • Cataracta nigra (black)
  • Cataracta rubra (red)

questions.text: The given phenomenon is not shown by _____
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Iceberg phenomenon of disease. It is not shown by Measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension, mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text:
Correctly match the following logos.
  1. Cytotoxic       
  2. Radiation          
  3. Biohazard
questions.solution: The correctly matched logos are as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the English epidemiologist in the picture below:
questions.solution:
John Snow

  • English epidemiologist; studied cholera and its association with polluted drinking water
  • Father of (Modern) Epidemiology
  • Often called as ‘Greatest Doctor’
  • Calculated dose of ether and chloroform as surgical anesthesia

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations should you advise this patient?

choices.text: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight serum cortisol measurement.

Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease.

Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. 

Risk factors for developing AF include:

  • Age- usually above 60 years of age
  • Underlying heart disease
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Sleep apnea
  • Post-cardiac surgery
  • Inflammatory pericarditis

Acute precipitating factors for AF include:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Acute alcohol intoxication
  • Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: An elderly patient was rushed to the casualty following bouts of severe breathlessness. He reported a history of fever and cough for the past 3 days. On examination, his SpO2 was 85% and RR was 32/min. CT scan is shown below. What is the gold standard investigation for his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with CT showing bilateral multiple patchy consolidation and grid-like thickness of interlobular septa, is suggestive of COVID-19. The gold standard for its diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA. Four regions of the SARS CoV2 genome are used as targets:

  • RdRp gene (RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) 
  • Genes from structural proteins 
    • E (virus envelope) 
    • N (virus nucleocapsid), 
  • ORF1ab gene (open reading frame 1a and 1b) 

CBNAAT (cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test) uses small, chip-based, portable, battery-operated devices that detect target genetic material of SARS CoV2. Examples include TrueNat and Cepheid Xpert Xpress SARS CoV-2

Options A and B: Antibody testing- Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

Option C: Rapid antigen test (RAT)- Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

ICMR has recently approved CoviSelf (nasal swab) for home testing of COVID-19 by RAT. It is advised only in symptomatic individuals and immediate contacts of laboratory confirmed positive cases. All individuals who test positive may be considered as true positives and no repeat testing is required.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He also complains of pain in his ankle and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratoderma blennorrhagica. The clinical scenario describes acute arthritis following a recent infection with an additive pattern (involvement of new joints within a few days). These features suggest the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is a condition included in the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies. It is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent oligoarthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27.

Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium.

The clinical features of reactive arthritis include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue, weight loss. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle. Sacroiliitis and spondylitis occur as late sequelae and are more commonly asymmetric. Non-marginal syndesmophytes which are comma-shaped arising from the middle of the vertebral body are seen. Dactylitis or sausage digit and enthesitis are also seen.

Extraarticular manifestation of reactive arthritis:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: Superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis: consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Conjunctivitis

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Synovial fluid analysis shows inflammatory changes with negative culture. Joint radiograph shows juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, and periostitis with new bone formation.

Treatment includes NSAIDs, intralesional glucocorticoids, and antibiotics during the antecedent infection.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months 

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

Sacro-iliac joints show cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints

Vertebral changes: Earliest change is the flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’). Bamboo spine appearance occurs due to bridging at several vertebral levels.

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance:

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or dactylitis, enthesitis. The inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints. There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping. Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers. Axial involvement may occur.

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"

X-ray shows 'pencil-in-cup' involving metacarpophalangeal joints:

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age. The patient usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal(MCP) and proximal interphalangeal(PIP) joints are commonly involved. The patient also has morning stiffness in the affected joints.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg as shown in the image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. What grade of lymphedema is this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bed rest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification.

Clinical classification of lymphedema:

Grade (Brunner)

Clinical features

Subclinical

There is excessive interstitial fluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, but no clinically apparent lymphedema.

Grade I

Edema pits on pressure and the swelling completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.

Grade II

Edema does not pit and does not significantly reduce on elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign

Grade III

Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes i.e. fibrosis and papillae.

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image:
questions.solution:
The stage of the given bedsore is Stage 4.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: This instrument is least useful in ________
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope.

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in acute anal fissure, but reserved for later, when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

questions.text: The sign shown in the given image represents _____
questions.solution:
In gallstones, the above computed tomography (CT) image shows the seagull/Mercedes-Benz sign.

  • A skillfully taken plain X-ray image of the gallbladder shows radiopaque gallstones in 10% of the patients.
  • Rarely, the centre of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure, and this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph—the "Mercedes–Benz" or "seagull" sign.

questions.text: Identify the suture used for management of PPH.
questions.solution:
The image is that of a uterine compression suture or a "brace" called the B-lynch suture.

  • It is a technique to arrest hemorrhage for severe postpartum atony.
  • B lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which appose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus which leads to compression of fundus and lower uterine segment thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: The following image shows ______

choices.text: Brandt Andrews method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The given image shows the Duncan method of placental separation.

Schultze Duncan
Separation begins from center of placenta to periphery. Separation begins from periphery to centre.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and uterine wall.
  • Brandt Andrew method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 
  • One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus.
  • While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Image A - Schultze, B - Mathew Duncan

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pigmentation of the face and severe backache and stiffness. The X-Ray image of the spine is as shown. Her urine color changes to black on standing. Which of the following drugs can be used in her treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the face and urine turning black on standing are associated with alkaptonuria. X-ray shows calcification of intervertebral discs called ochronotic spondyloarthropathy also seen in alkaptonuria. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment of alkaptonuria. 

Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD) (early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acid production in alkaptonuria. Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic. In presymptomatic individuals, treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and a tyrosine restricted diet can be tried.

The patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing as shown below in the image.

questions.text: A patient who suffered an epileptic attack at home presented with pain over the left shoulder. An  AP view  X-ray of the shoulder was done, as shown below. Which of the following signs is seen here?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a history of an epileptic attack, along with an X-ray showing a light bulb contour of the humeral head on the AP radiograph of the left shoulder, is indicative of posterior shoulder dislocation.

In posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus rotates internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views.

Other radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • The rim sign: Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm
  • The vacant glenoid sign: The glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it
  • The trough sign: A vertical line is seen on the anteromedial part of humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum   

Option A: Comolli's sign is seen in scapular fracture.

Option C: Destot's sign is seen in pelvic fracture.

Option D: Oliver's sign is seen in aortic aneurysm.

questions.text:
Abuse of which of the following drugs will lead to the finding as shown in the image below?
  1. Heroin
  2. Cocaine
  3. LSD
  4. Mescaline
  5. Cannabis
questions.solution:
The given image shows circular depressed skin popping scars in this patient. Among the given options, opioid abuse and cocaine abuse are the most likely causes of the skin popping scars in this patient.

Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Drugs like heroin, cocaine, barbiturates can be injected intradermally or subcutaneously with the goal of achieving slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration than with intravenous drug use.

LSD and mescaline (hallucinogens) and cannabis are not taken through injections, but by oral route or through smoking.

Head-to-toe examination in cases of substance abuse becomes important to look for such skin findings. One other such interesting finding seen in patients with cocaine abuse is that its long-term use can result in cocaine nose, with perforation of the nasal septum, as seen in the image below.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: The following device is most suitable for _______.
questions.solution:
The image given is the south oral Ring-Adair-Elwyn (RAE) endotracheal tube.

It is preferable for nasal and ophthalmic surgeries because it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it does not disrupt the surgical field.

Other specialized endotracheal tubes and its uses:

  • Flexometalllic (Armored or reinforced tubes): head and neck surgery
  • Microlaryngeal tubes: laryngeal surgery
  • Double-lumen endotracheal tubes: thoracic surgery

North nasal RAE tube has the tube connector facing towards the patient's head after placement. These are used in oral surgeries.

Image: The above image shows south faced oral RAE tube for a cleft lip surgery.

Image: The above image shows a north nasal RAE tube for oral surgery

questions.text: Identify the skin condition in the image given below.
questions.solution:
• Rhinophyma (also known as Potato nose) is a slowly benign progressive condition due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose often seen in cases of long-standing rosacea called Phymatous rosacea. It is the most common manifestation of phymatous rosacea.

Clinical Picture

  • It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation.
  • It mostly affects men past middle age.
  • Patients seek advice because of the distorted appearance of the enlarged nose, or obstruction in breathing and vision.

Diagnosis

  • Rhinophyma may be diagnosed clinically, but a skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.
  • On histology, Rhinophyma shows sebaceous gland hypertrophy,hyperplasia and fibrosis.

Treatment

  • The most common indication for treatment is cosmetic.
  • Ablation using CO2 laser or surgical resection of excess tissue with remodelling of nose can be performed.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of neck stiffness and severe headache with CT revealing blood in the basal cistern points out to the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region, or in the Sylvian fissure.

Young males with a history of spontaneous sudden onset severe headache with seizures should raise suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage (aneurysmal). The most common cause of SAH is head trauma and the second common cause is rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

Symptoms include:

  • Severe headache (thunderclap headache)
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness
  • Seizures
  • Neck stiffness or neck pain

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MR-Angiography shown is of Vein of Galen Malformation.

Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM's), also known as median prosencephalic arteriovenous fistula, are uncommon intracranial anomalies that tend to present in early childhood with features of a left-to-right shunt and high-output cardiac failure.

The vein of Galen, also known as the great cerebral vein or great vein of Galen, is a short trunk formed by the union of the two internal cerebral veins and basal veins of Rosenthal. It lies in the quadrigeminal cistern. It curves backward and upward around the posterior border of the splenium of the corpus callosum and drains the anterior and central regions of the brain into the sinuses of the posterior cerebral fossa.
